page.title: 01LANDSCAPE, EAST BARKWITH
page.content: This block covers an undulating landscape, rising from a height of 40 metres above sea-level in the south west, to some 80 metres in the east. The higher land is part of the { {Lincolnshire Wolds,}which are chalk, over-lying sandstone, with glacial outwash of sand and clays to the west. Two villages,{East Barkwith} and { {South Willingham,}are included in the area, with parts of the parishes of East Torrington, Benniworth and Hainton. The area is agricultural, predominantly arable. The woodlands are deciduous, and were planted as fox coverts, or as amenity woodland associated with Panton Hall, now demolished, or Hainton Hall.
